text:
What's the national speed limit for cars and 
motorcycles on a dual 
carriageway?

options.A: 30 mph
options.B: 70 mph
options.C: 60 mph
options.D: 50 mph

explanation: 70 mph. The national speed limit for cars on dual carriageways is 70 mph.

text:
There are no speed-limit signs on the road. In 
England, Scotland and 
Northern Ireland how is a 30 mph limit generally 
indicated?

options.A: By pedestrian islands
options.B: By double or single yellow lines
options.C: By hazard warning lines
options.D: By street lighting

explanation: 60 mph. The national speed limit on single carriageways is 60 mph for cars and motorcycles.

text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland what will the speed limit usually be where you can see street lights but no speed-limit 
signs?

options.A: 60 mph
options.B: 30 mph
options.C: 40 mph
options.D: 50 mph

explanation: 30 mph. Unless otherwise stated, the speed limit in built-up areas with street lighting is 30 mph.

text:
What does this sign
mean?

options.A: End of maximum speed
options.B: Maximum speed 30 mph
options.C: Minimum speed 30 mph
options.D: End of minimum speed

explanation: Red and amber together. Red and amber together means stop, prepare to go - the lights are about to change to green.

text:
What should you do if you
want to overtake a tractor
but aren't sure that it's safe?

options.A: Sound your horn to make the tractor driver pull over
options.B: Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor
options.C: Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
options.D: Stay behind it if you're in any doubt

explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop. Flashing amber lights mean you can proceed only if it's safe and pedestrians have crossed.

text: Which vehicle is most likely to take an unusual course at a roundabout?

options.A: Taxi
options.B: Long vehicle
options.C: Delivery van
options.D: Estate car

explanation: Give way to traffic already on the roundabout. Traffic on the roundabout has priority over vehicles entering.

text:
When may you stop on a
clearway?

options.A: During daylight hours
options.B: Never
options.C: When it's busy
options.D: In the rush hour

explanation: Move to the left and slow down. When emergency vehicles approach with lights/sirens, move left and slow to let them pass.

text:
What's the meaning of
this sign?

options.A: Waiting restrictions
options.B: National speed limit
options.C: School crossing patrol
options.D: No entry

explanation: Stop and wait. A red traffic light means you must stop and wait behind the stop line.

text:
You're looking for
somewhere to park at night.
When may you park on the
right-hand side of the road?

options.A: When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction
options.B: When you're under a lamppost
options.C: When you have your sidelights on
options.D: When you're in a one-way street

explanation: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing. You must give way to pedestrians already on a zebra crossing.

text:
When should you use the
right-hand lane of a three-
lane dual carriageway?

options.A: When you're using cruise control
options.B: When you're overtaking only
options.C: When you're turning right only
options.D: When you're overtaking or turning right

explanation: Give way to traffic from the right. At unmarked junctions, give way to traffic approaching from your right.

text:
You're approaching a
busy junction. What should
you do when, at the last
moment, you realise you're
in the wrong lane?

options.A: Force your way into the lane you need
options.B: Use arm signals to help you change lane
options.C: Stop until the area has cleared
options.D: Continue in that lane

explanation: No stopping at any time. Double yellow lines mean no stopping or parking at any time.

text:
Where may you overtake
on a one-way street?

options.A: Only on the right-hand side
options.B: On either the right or the left
options.C: Overtaking isn't allowed
options.D: Only on the left-hand side

explanation: Overtake on either side. On one-way streets, you can overtake on either the left or right side.

text:
What signal should you
give when you're going
straight ahead at a
roundabout?

options.A: Signal left before leaving the roundabout
options.B: Signal left when you're approaching the roundabout
options.C: Signal right when you're approaching the roundabout
options.D: Don't signal at any time

explanation: 70 mph. The motorway speed limit for cars is 70 mph.

text:
Which vehicle might
have to take a different
course from normal at a
roundabout?

options.A: Long vehicle
options.B: Van
options.C: Estate car
options.D: Sports car

explanation: Stop before the line. A solid white line means you must stop at the line.

text:
When may you enter a
box junction?

options.A: When there are fewer than two vehicles ahead
options.B: When your exit road is clear
options.C: When signalled by another road user
options.D: When traffic signs direct you

explanation: In the left-hand lane. On motorways, drive in the left lane unless overtaking.

text:
When may you stop and
wait in a box junction?

options.A: When you're on a roundabout
options.B: When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right
options.C: When you're in a queue of traffic turning left
options.D: When you're in a queue of traffic going ahead

explanation: Stop if pedestrians are waiting to cross. At pelican crossings, you must stop when the light is red.

text:
Who is authorised to
signal you to stop?

options.A: A motorcyclist
options.B: A bus driver
options.C: A police officer
options.D: A pedestrian

explanation: No vehicles except bicycles. This sign indicates a route for bicycles only.

text:
What should you do if
you see a pedestrian waiting
at a zebra crossing?

options.A: Be ready to slow down or stop to let them cross
options.B: Ignore them as they're still on the pavement
options.C: Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross
options.D: Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing

explanation: Give way to oncoming traffic. When the arrow points up, oncoming traffic has priority.

text:
You’re waiting at a
pelican crossing. What does
it mean when the red light
changes to flashing amber?

options.A: Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows
options.B: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing
options.C: Move off immediately without any hesitation
options.D: Wait for the green light before moving off

explanation: Wait until you're sure it's safe. At stop signs, you must stop completely and only proceed when safe.

text:
You see these double
white lines along the centre
of the road. When may you
park on the left?

options.A: To pick up or set down passengers
options.B: If the line nearest to you is broken
options.C: When there are no yellow lines
options.D: During daylight hours only

explanation: Move to the left. When an ambulance approaches with flashing lights, move left to allow it to pass.

text:
You're turning right at a crossroads. An oncoming driver is also turning right.
What's the advantage of turning behind the 
oncoming vehicle?

options.A: You'll use less fuel because you can stay in a higher gear
options.B: You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic
options.C: You'll be able to turn without stopping
options.D: You'll have more time to turn

explanation: 50 mph. The national speed limit for cars towing trailers on single carriageways is 50 mph.

text:
You're travelling along a
residential street. There are
parked vehicles on the left-
hand side. Why should you
keep your speed down?

options.A: So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly
options.B: Children may run out from between the vehicles
options.C: There may be delivery lorries on the street
options.D: You may set off car alarms

explanation: Clearway - no stopping. A clearway means no stopping at any time except in an emergency.

text:
When would you use the
right-hand lane of a two-lane
dual carriageway?

options.A: When you're travelling at a constant high speed
options.B: When you're turning right or overtaking
options.C: When you're passing a side road on the left
options.D: When you're staying at the minimum allowed speed

explanation: No entry. This sign means no entry for vehicles in this direction.

text:
You're looking for
somewhere to safely park
your vehicle. Where would
you choose to park?

options.A: Near the brow of a hill
options.B: In a designated parking space
options.C: At or near a bus stop
options.D: On the approach to a level crossing

explanation: Stop at the line. At traffic lights, stop before the solid white stop line.

text:
You're waiting at a level
crossing. What must you do
if a train passes but the
lights keep flashing?

options.A: Phone the signal operator
options.B: Carry on waiting
options.C: Park and investigate
options.D: Edge over the stop line and look for trains

explanation: Before you reach the crossing. Always check mirrors before any maneuver, including approaching crossings.

text:
What does this sign
mean?

options.A: Free-parking zone ends
options.B: End of controlled parking zone
options.C: End of traffic-calming zone
options.D: No through road

explanation: Wait behind the line. At red lights with a green filter arrow, wait unless turning in the direction shown by the arrow.

text:
What must you do if you come across roadworks that have a temporary speed 
limit displayed?

options.A: Obey the limit, but only during rush hour
options.B: Use your own judgement; the limit is only advisory
options.C: Obey the speed limit
options.D: Ignore the displayed limit

explanation: On the left. In the UK, you should normally drive on the left side of the road.

text:
You're in a built-up area
at night and the road is well
lit. Why should you use
dipped headlights?

options.A: So that you can switch to main beam quickly
options.B: So that you can be easily seen by others
options.C: So that you can go at a much faster speed
options.D: So that you can see further along the road

explanation: No motor vehicles. This sign prohibits all motor vehicles from entering.

text:
You're turning right onto
a dual carriageway. What
should you do if the central
reservation is too narrow to
contain your vehicle?

options.A: Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
options.B: Emerge slightly to show your intentions
options.C: Proceed to the central reservation and wait
options.D: Wait until the road is clear in both directions

explanation: Move over to let it pass. Emergency vehicles on calls should be allowed to pass quickly and safely.

text:
What's the national
speed limit on a single
carriageway road for cars
and motorcycles?

options.A: 60 mph
options.B: 30 mph
options.C: 50 mph
options.D: 70 mph

explanation: 60 mph. The national speed limit on single carriageways for cars is 60 mph.

text:
What should you do
when you park at night on a
road that has a 40 mph
speed limit?

options.A: Leave parking lights switched on
options.B: Park near a street light
options.C: Leave dipped headlights switched on
options.D: Park facing the traffic

explanation: Stop. A school crossing patrol showing a stop sign means you must stop.

text:
Where will you see these
red and white markers?

options.A: Approaching the end of a dual carriageway
options.B: Approaching the end of a motorway
options.C: Approaching a concealed level crossing
options.D: Approaching a concealed speed-limit sign

explanation: Pedestrians have priority. At zebra crossings, you must give way to pedestrians crossing or waiting to cross.

text:
You're travelling on a
motorway in England. When
must you stop your vehicle?

options.A: When signalled to stop by a traffic officer
options.B: When signalled to stop by a roadworks supervisor
options.C: When signalled to stop by a driver who has broken down
options.D: When signalled to stop by a pedestrian on the hard shoulder

explanation: Give way to traffic from the right. Unless signs indicate otherwise, give way to traffic from the right at roundabouts.

text:
How should you signal if
you're going straight ahead
at a roundabout?

options.A: Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take
options.B: Signal left after you leave the roundabout and enter the new road
options.C: Signal right on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on
options.D: Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the roundabout

explanation: To tell you the speed limit. Speed limit signs inform you of the maximum permitted speed.

text:
When may you drive
over a pavement?

options.A: To overtake slow-moving traffic
options.B: When the pavement is very wide
options.C: To gain access to a property
options.D: If there are no pedestrians nearby

explanation: No overtaking. This sign prohibits overtaking on that section of road.

text: A single carriageway road has this sign. What's the maximum permitted speed for a car towing a trailer?

options.A: 50 mph
options.B: 60 mph
options.C: 40 mph
options.D: 30 mph

explanation: Get into the right-hand lane. When turning right at a roundabout, move to the right lane before entering.

text: What's the speed limit for a car towing a caravan on a dual carriageway?

options.A: 70 mph
options.B: 60 mph
options.C: 40 mph
options.D: 50 mph

explanation: At a junction. Box junctions prevent blocking intersections - don't enter unless your exit is clear.

text:
You want to park and you
see this sign. What should
you do on the days and
times shown?

options.A: Park on yellow lines and not pay
options.B: Park in a bay and not pay
options.C: Park on yellow lines and pay
options.D: Park in a bay and pay

explanation: Stop at the line. Solid white stop lines mean you must stop before the line.

text:
A cycle lane, marked by
a solid white line, is in
operation. What does this
mean for car drivers?

options.A: They may park in the lane
options.B: They may drive in the lane at any time
options.C: They may use the lane when necessary
options.D: They mustn't drive along the lane

explanation: Proceed with caution. Green lights mean proceed if safe, but always check for other traffic.

text:
You're going to turn left
from a main road into a
minor road. What should
you do as you approach the
junction?

options.A: Keep just left of the middle of the road
options.B: Keep well to the left of the road
options.C: Swing out to the right just before turning
options.D: Keep in the middle of the road

explanation: Hold back until the cyclist has passed. Give cyclists space and time to pass junctions safely.

text: You're waiting at a level crossing. What should you do if the red warning lights continue to flash after a train has passed by?

options.A: Get out and investigate
options.B: Telephone the signal operator
options.C: Continue to wait
options.D: Drive across carefully

explanation: No vehicles. This indicates an area where no vehicles are permitted.

text: What should you do if the amber lights come on and a warning sounds while you're driving over a level crossing?

options.A: Get everyone out of the vehicle immediately
options.B: Stop immediately and use your hazard warning lights
options.C: Keep going and clear the crossing
options.D: Stop and reverse back to clear the crossing

explanation: Wait before the line. Never cross solid white stop lines, even when the way seems clear.

text:
You're driving on a busy
main road. What should you
do if you find that you're
driving in the wrong
direction?

options.A: Turn around in a side road
options.B: Make a ‘three-point’ turn in the main road
options.C: Make a U-turn in the main road
options.D: Turn into a side road on the right and reverse into the main road

explanation: Red route - no stopping. Red routes have strict stopping restrictions at all times.

text:
When may you drive
without wearing your seat
belt?

options.A: When you're driving slowly in queuing traffic
options.B: When you're testing your brakes
options.C: When you're moving off on a hill
options.D: When you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing

explanation: Give way to pedestrians. At crossings, pedestrians have priority when crossing.

text:
How far are you allowed
to reverse?

options.A: The length of a residential street
options.B: As far as it takes to reverse around a corner
options.C: No more than a car’s length
options.D: No further than is necessary

explanation: 70 mph. The national speed limit on dual carriageways for cars is 70 mph.

text:
What should you do 
when you're unsure whether it's safe to reverse your 
vehicle?

options.A: Rev your engine
options.B: Sound your horn
options.C: Reverse slowly
options.D: Get out and check

explanation: Move left to let it pass. Always give way to emergency vehicles with blue flashing lights.

text:
Why could it be
dangerous to reverse from a
side road into a main road?

options.A: Your reversing lights will be hidden
options.B: Your reverse sensors will beep
options.C: Your view will be restricted
options.D: Your mirrors will need adjusting

explanation: 30 mph. This is the standard speed limit in built-up areas with street lighting.

text:
You want to turn right at
a box junction. What should
you do if there's oncoming
traffic?

options.A: Drive on; you can't turn right at a box junction
options.B: Wait in the box junction if your exit is clear
options.C: Wait before the junction until it's clear of all traffic
options.D: Drive slowly into the box junction when signalled by oncoming traffic

explanation: Stop and give way. At give way signs and lines, you must give priority to traffic on the major road.

text:
You're reversing into a
side road. When would your
vehicle be the greatest
hazard to passing traffic?

options.A: After you’ve completed the manoeuvre
options.B: When the front of your vehicle swings out
options.C: After you’ve entered the side road
options.D: Just before you begin to manoeuvre

explanation: Give way to traffic from the right. This is the basic rule at roundabouts without priority markings.

text:
Where's the safest place
to park your vehicle at
night?

options.A: In a quiet car park
options.B: On a busy road
options.C: In a garage
options.D: Near a red route

explanation: Traffic lights out of order. This means the traffic lights aren't working - treat as an unmarked junction.

text:
When may you stop on
an urban clearway?

options.A: To set down and pick up passengers
options.B: To use a mobile telephone
options.C: To ask for directions
options.D: To load or unload goods

explanation: No parking. This sign indicates parking is not permitted in this area.

text:
You're looking for 
somewhere to park your 
vehicle. Neither you or your passenger are disabled.
What should you do if the only free spaces are marked for disabled drivers?

options.A: Use one of the spaces as long as one is kept free
options.B: Park in one of these spaces but stay with your vehicle
options.C: Use one of these spaces
options.D: Wait for a regular parking space to become free

explanation: When your exit is clear. Only enter box junctions when your exit road is clear.

text:
You're on a road that's
only wide enough for one
vehicle. What should you do
if a car is coming towards
you?

options.A: Pull into a passing place on your right
options.B: Pull into a passing place on your left
options.C: Force the other driver to reverse
options.D: Pull into a passing place if your vehicle is wider

explanation: Stop completely. Stop signs require a complete stop before proceeding.

text:
You're driving at night with your headlights on main beam. A vehicle is overtaking you. When 
should you dip your 
headlights?

options.A: Some time after the vehicle has passed you
options.B: Before the vehicle starts to pass you
options.C: Only if the other driver dips their headlights
options.D: As soon as the vehicle passes you

explanation: Pedestrians have priority. Always give way to pedestrians at zebra crossings.

text:
When may you drive a
car in this bus lane?

options.A: To overtake slow-moving traffic
options.B: You may not use it at any time
options.C: To get to the front of a traffic queue
options.D: Outside its hours of operation

explanation: Drive at 30 mph. In built-up areas with street lighting, the limit is 30 mph unless otherwise stated.

text:
Other than direction
indicators, how can you give
signals to other road users?

options.A: By using interior lights
options.B: By using brake lights
options.C: By using sidelights
options.D: By using fog lights

explanation: On the left-hand side. In the UK, you should drive on the left unless overtaking or turning right.

text:
You're parked in a busy high street. What's the 
safest way to turn your 
vehicle around so you can drive in the opposite 
direction?

options.A: Turn around in a quiet side road
options.B: Carry out a U-turn
options.C: Ask someone to stop the traffic
options.D: Drive into a side road and reverse out into the main road

explanation: Minimum speed limit. This sign shows the minimum speed vehicles must maintain.

text:
You're driving in the 
right-hand lane of a dual 
carriageway. What should you do if you see a sign 
showing that the right-hand lane is closed 800 yards 
ahead?

options.A: Move to the left in good time
options.B: Keep in that lane until you reach the queue
options.C: Move to the left immediately
options.D: Wait and see which lane is moving faster

explanation: Move to the left in good time. When you see advance warning signs of lane closures, merge in good time - don't wait until the last moment.

text: You're driving on a road that has a cycle lane. What does it mean if the lane is marked by a broken white line?

options.A: There's a reduced speed limit for motor vehicles using the lane
options.B: You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable
options.C: Cyclists can travel in both directions in that lane
options.D: The lane must be used by motorcyclists in heavy traffic

explanation: You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable. Broken white lines indicate advisory cycle lanes - avoid using them but you can if necessary.

text:
When are you allowed to
park in a parking bay for
disabled drivers?

options.A: When you have an advanced driver certificate
options.B: When you have a Blue Badge
options.C: When you have an adapted vehicle
options.D: When you have a wheelchair

explanation: When you have a Blue Badge. Only vehicles displaying a valid Blue Badge can park in disabled bays.

text:
When must you stop
your vehicle?

options.A: At a junction where there are ‘give way’ lines
options.B: Before merging onto a motorway
options.C: At the end of a one-way street
options.D: If you’re involved in an incident that causes damage or injury

explanation: If you're involved in an incident that causes damage or injury. You must stop by law if you're involved in any incident causing damage or injury.
